thread.title: Father-son dynamic a winner for Stovers, Upper Dublin
thread.title_full: Father-son dynamic a winner for Stovers, Upper Dublin

author: Rick O'Brien,
title: Father-son dynamic a winner for Stovers, Upper Dublin
text:
There's a certain dynamic when a father coaches his quarterback-playing son. Depending on the personalities involved, it can be a positive and bonding experience or a trying one filled with tension.
Bret Stover, Upper Dublin's head coach, and Ryan Stover, the Cardinals' quarterback, have successfully navigated the potentially tricky and delicate path.
Bret Stover was a quarterback at Upper Dublin (Class of 1984) and Millersville, where he threw for 2,449 yards and 22 touchdowns in two years as a starter. In youth football, Ryan mostly played tight end on offense. He moved to quarterback in eighth grade.
"I didn't want to push him into playing quarterback," Bret Stover said. "If he wanted to play the position, great. If he didn't, that was fine too."
More coverage Latest high school sports scores Local high school standings More coverage: New Jersey high school sports More coverage: Southeastern Pa. high school sports Ryan Stover saw time at quarterback as a sophomore and took over as starter last year. "I always thought I had it in my genes because of what my dad did," he said. "And then I found the position to be a good fit with my skills."
In leading Upper Dublin to a 6-0 overall record and 3-0 mark in the Suburban One League American Conference, Stover has completed 39 of 53 passes for 679 yards and eight touchdowns. The 6-foot-4, 205-pound senior has carried 29 times for 400 yards and five touchdowns.
"His decision-making, even early on, was very good," Bret Stover said. "And he's really become a student of the game. He's good at making adjustments."
The red-hot Cardinals, who have outscored foes by 288-24, visit conference rival Plymouth Whitemarsh (5-1, 2-1) at 7 p.m. Friday.
Last season, Stover passed for 2,187 yards and 21 touchdowns while helping Upper Dublin go 11-2, win the conference title, and advance to the PIAA District 1 Class AAAA semifinals.
Toward the end of last year, Bret Stover, a health and physical education teacher at Upper Dublin, allowed Ryan to sometimes call his own plays. "Not a lot of high school quarterbacks get that chance, so I welcomed it," Ryan said.
Of the football relationship he has with his father, the 17-year-old said, "He doesn't treat me any differently than our other players. But he expects a little more of me as a team leader and captain."
In the offseason, Ryan Stover participated in camps at Delaware, Kutztown, Richmond, Lehigh, Pittsburgh, and Temple. No BCS or FBS offer came from the trips.
Towson recently became the first FBS program to offer a scholarship. "I was very happy that something finally happened," said Ryan Stover, who plans to major in accounting in college.
Delaware, Colgate, Holy Cross, Richmond, and William and Mary have expressed varying degrees of interest.
For now, the Stovers are focused on duplicating or bettering last year's record-setting campaign.
"I've watched so many of our guys play together since they were 7 or 8 years old," Bret Stover said. "That's one of the exciting parts about this."
